Randle Patrick McMurphy.Action: Sits resolutely alone on top of the water tower, ignoring calls and threats below.
Climbs the water tower despite injury and exhaustion, uses silence and patience as a tactic against the officials.
Remains non-responsive to repeated calls and threats, demonstrating control and strategic non-engagement.
Does a couple of knee bends to get the kinks out of his legs after emerging from the car, showing readiness and physical control.
Emerges calmly and confidently from the police car in handcuffs, dressed in his distinct clothes, indicating self-assuredness and control of the situation.
Impulsively kisses Deputy's forehead as cuffs are removed.
Greets Nurse Itsu warmly and playfully calls her 'cutie', making her laugh.
Acknowledges Nurse Pilbow politely and follows her closely despite her nervousness.
Impulsively kisses the Deputy's forehead upon cuff removal.
Engages Nurse Pilbow and other staff confidently with casual, friendly talk, showing social ease.
Responds to the Deputies and surroundings with calm, collected remarks indicating situational awareness.
Casual and flippant attitude towards authority figures, potentially undermining seriousness of situation.
Polite gesture saying 'After you, ma'am' to Nurse Pilbow.
Makes a crude comment about 'poontang' around here upon entering the ward.
Engages in lighthearted banter with Doctor Spivey about fishing, matching the doctor's mood.
Shakes hands with Doctor Spivey and introduces himself politely.
Responds enthusiastically and shares stories about his fishing experiences.
Politely thanks Nurse Pilbow when invited to make himself at home.
Confidently describes his fishing experience and background to Doc Spivey, demonstrating self-assuredness and clear communication.
Engages politely and appropriately in a new environment, shaking hands and replying respectfully to staff.
Smiles and tips his hat to Big Nurse, who smiles back.
Greets Sefelt with a friendly 'Hi.'
Initiates conversation with a lonely patient by asking 'How ya doin', buddy?'
Responds empathetically to patient's complaint of having a fever.
Clarifies he is not a doctor when asked, doing so politely.
Refuses Martini's request for change but engages friendly conversation with him and others.
Shares his cigarettes willingly with Scanlon and Martini.
Shows gentle concern by asking Taber what's troubling him and challenges his fatalistic view.
Engages with the old man in a light, somewhat affectionate way despite the man's limited communication.
Uses mild teasing language (e.g., 'deaf and dumb Indian') reflecting casual camaraderie without malice.
Hands out cigarettes readily to others and engages in casual conversation with patients.
Questions Taber about his fatalistic attitude and points out he is still breathing, showing situational awareness and interpersonal engagement.
Acknowledges the poor condition of the hospital but compares it to the worse conditions he came from, demonstrating perspective and confidence.
Does not follow through with writing the letter for money despite Taber's request and distress.
Introduces himself warmly to Billy and shakes his hand, using a friendly tone.
Initiates casual conversation and shows interest in patients by asking about the 'top loony' around.
Sits close to Harding despite his nervousness, showing a willingness to engage directly.
Approaches the card game confidently, initiates friendly interaction by shaking hands with Billy, and confidently seeks out the leader of the group.
Sits down uninvited next to Harding to observe and engage, showing social confidence and savvy in navigating group dynamics.
Responds to challenges about needing an appointment with calm assertiveness by stating he can wait, showing patience and control.
Slides into Harding's seat and takes over the card game, entertaining others with his card tricks and friendly demeanor.
Asks others to 'hold the fort down' when leaving the game to go with Big Nurse, showing trust and camaraderie.
Slides into Harding's seat and rakes all the cards in one swift movement, impressing others with his skill as a card shark.
Responds calmly and confidently to Big Nurse when asked to come with her, showing composure during an initial formal encounter.
Thanks Big Nurse for appreciating his effort to meet other patients; politely responds to her instructions.
Expresses desire to call his aunt so she can visit him, showing concern for family connection.
Tells Big Nurse he is glad to be here and compliments her appearance in a friendly manner.
Does not immediately move when asked to follow someone, subtly asserting himself, but still polite when prompted.
Politely engages with Big Nurse, follows instructions, and shows awareness of social norms in a new environment.
Pauses instead of immediately moving with Mister Washington when directed, indicating a measured response rather than automatic compliance.
Attempts to initiate a friendly and slightly flirtatious exchange with Big Nurse, demonstrating social confidence and skill.
Openly shares his life story and past with Doctor Spivey in a straightforward manner.
Dismisses the label of 'habitual hassler' and expresses frustration about social persecution.
Denies the accusation of being a disturbing influence or instigating revolt.
Confidently describes his diverse past skills and roles to Doctor Spivey, showing self-awareness and ability to adapt.
Acknowledges legal troubles and reputation without defensiveness, suggesting realistic self-assessment.
Does not directly confront or argue with Doctor Spivey about disturbing influence report, instead deflects with a casual remark.
Answers questions directly and confidently to the psychiatrist during intake.
Acknowledges court-ordered observation with willingness to cooperate.
Gets up during the meeting and unhooks Ellis from the wall where he is soiled and left hanging, moving him to a more dignified position despite the rule against leaving seats.
Expresses sympathy for Ellis by saying it pains him to see a man sloshing in his own urine, showing concern for others' dignity.
Offers a cigarette to Harding, initiating friendly interaction.
Mocks the group therapy meeting by calling it a 'peckin' party' and criticizes the nurse's behavior.
Comforts Harding by acknowledging the harshness of Nurse Ratched's control, using humor and physical teasing to lighten the mood.
Attempts to encourage defiance against Nurse Ratched's authority to protect his fellow patients.
Dismisses Harding's respectful attempt to view Nurse Ratched as competent, instead framing her as an oppressor.
Shows sincere concern and surprise upon learning about the consequences of resistance, such as Electro-Shock Therapy and Lobotomy.
Organizes and runs a blackjack game among patients, loaning cigarettes to Cheswick when he can't pay, engaging with patients in a playful manner.
Skillfully runs a blackjack game, confidently manages bets and markers, keeps track of multiple players and the cards, handles distractions yet continues the game smoothly.
Distracted by the Sports on TV while dealing cards and running the game.
Shouts friendly questions to fellow patients during a card game.
Politely asks Nurse Pilbow to turn something off.
Complies respectfully when Big Nurse tells him patients aren't allowed in the nurses' station.
Does not take his medication despite getting the cup.
Turns up to the nurses' station to question medication rules directly, tries to assert himself despite Nurse Pilbow's fear and Big Nurse's authority.
Successfully navigates social interactions confidently by apologizing and stepping back when ordered, showing situational awareness.
Does not take his pills when reaching for medication, suggesting a deliberate choice and subtle resistance, indicating strategic thinking.
Politely asks the nurse to lower the music so he can think, then apologizes sincerely when told no and wipes the window clean.
Questions the nurse firmly but not rudely about the medication before taking it.
Politely asks the nurse to turn down the music to better hear himself think, showing assertiveness and social tact.
Leans against the glass despite being told it stains, then quickly apologizes and cleans it, demonstrating awareness and adaptability.
Questions the medication he is supposed to take, refusing to swallow something without knowing what it is, showing critical thinking and confidence.
Takes his medication cooperatively despite making a show of it, then smiles at concerned faces.
Flicks his pill into Harding's forehead playfully, engaging with other patients in teasing banter.
Insults Big Nurse harshly over the intercom, calling her 'icy-hearted' and disparaging her personally.
Takes medication publicly showing compliance but with a playful attitude, flicking the pill at Harding and joking.
Verbally challenges Big Nurse with sarcastic and confident remarks, maintaining control of the situation and the group's attention.
Does not directly confront or insult Big Nurse but uses humor to undermine authority, showing social awareness and skill.
Quietly offers a fresh piece of gum to Bromden while he chews stale gum, using a playful song to engage him.
Quietly offering a fresh piece of gum to Bromden during the night and engaging him with a playful song, showing thoughtful and considerate behavior.
Successfully reading Bromden's silent signals and responding appropriately, indicating social awareness and emotional intelligence.
Slowly pulls himself together to get up despite not being ready for the day; searches his drawer for cigarettes indicating a personal routine.
Expresses frustration when discovering his cigarettes are missing.
Attempts to lighten the mood by singing loudly and leading others to brush their teeth.
Asks Big Nurse to ‘spring a pack of cigarettes loose’ on behalf of the group.
Complains about ward rules using sarcastic language (‘You sure run a tight-assed ship...’).
Sings loudly and irreverently, expressing a carefree and jovial attitude.
Questions the restrained behavior of other patients during mealtime and encourages them to eat with enthusiasm.
Makes a lighthearted, joking comment about the lack of women to liven up the place.
Challenges Washington by trying to leave the ward before allowed.
Sings loudly and irreverently while entering the washroom, showing confidence and disregard for authority.
Questions why the others are behaving passively and not eating, indicating awareness and insight into the situation.
Eats heartily and comfortably, indicating confidence and adaptation to the environment.
Attempts to leave before the official allowed time, but pauses on calculating the exact time suggests cautiousness and situational awareness.
Calls Washington 'Asshole' and turns away, ending conversation abruptly.
Does not respond or support Cheswick when he seeks backing against Big Nurse.
Volunteers to speak up in the group meeting, intending to express his honest thoughts.
Considers the needs of both young and old patients by suggesting louder music for the old and a separate game room for the young, aiming to improve ward life for all.
Proposes switching group meeting time to watch the World Series and encourages patients to vote on it.
Expresses frustration when few patients support his idea and they quickly withdraw support.
Attempts to assert his idea to change the schedule for a game by calling a vote and pushing the issue confidently before the group.
Fails to realize or anticipate that most patients are unlikely or unwilling to support his proposal, leading to a nearly unanimous rejection and failure to achieve his goal.
Slouches in his chair, not participating in group discussion when Harding is speaking.
Plays a game of monopoly with Martini, Scanlon, and Cheswick, engaging with other patients.
Organizes and leads a game of Monopoly to engage others.
Scolds others for messing around and causing trouble during the game.
Slams fist on the table, disrupting the game and upsetting Martini.
Encourages others to vote and get involved, shows desire to bring excitement (baseball game) to the ward.
Challenges others with bets and taunts (e.g. using Sefelt’s head as a battering ram).
Engages the group in a challenge and playful betting to boost morale and provoke confidence.
Slams fist and causes disruption during the game out of frustration or anger.
Attempts the strenuous machine challenge despite physical limits, then admits he tried his best and shows frustration at his own failure.
Reassures Billy by refusing to be angry at him for previous actions, attributing blame to himself instead.
Turns away from Billy when approached and initially shows some distance.
Encourages the group by saying they need to pull the team together for the next play.
Defends Billy during Group Meeting by telling Big Nurse to get off his back and move on, showing protective attitude.
Intervenes in group meeting to defend Billy and redirect attention, showing awareness and confidence in social situation.
Challenges the group therapy session and pushes for a vote on watching the ballgame instead.
Leads the voting, confidently counting hands and celebrating the win before realizing the vote is not in their favor.
Fails to notice that most patients did not raise their hands, indicating a misjudgment of the group’s support.
Insists on counting the votes of all patients including the ones Big Nurse ignores, standing up for fairness and inclusion.
Turns on the television against Big Nurse’s command and invites others to join him in watching the ballgame, creating a moment of shared enjoyment.
Challenges Big Nurse's rule about vote counting and insists on including all patient votes despite previous practice.
Turns on the television and engages the patients with the ballgame to boost morale and distract them.
Defies Big Nurse's orders by turning on the TV and refusing to sit quietly, showing confidence and initiative.
Encourages the Acutes to engage with the TV game by enthusiastically commentating and cheering, creating a sense of camaraderie and excitement.
Energetically leads the group in a vivid, imaginative baseball commentary on a blank TV, engaging and energizing the others despite the nonsensical situation.
Deliberately violates the rules by ignoring Big Nurse’s commands, risking punishment to assert control and boost morale.
Leads the Acutes in a spontaneous, joyful celebration, cheering and dancing in each other's arms.
Responds to Doctor Spivey with casual humor and a friendly demeanor, indicating ease and openness.
Acknowledges his disruptive influence on the ward but frames it as challenging the nurse's rigid authority rather than harming patients.
Enthusiastically leads the Acutes in a lively, imaginative baseball scenario despite Big Nurse's prohibition, demonstrating confidence and leadership.
Openly challenges Big Nurse's authority and criticizes her 'fixed ways' when talking to Doctor Spivey, showing insight and assertiveness.
Admits to Doctor Spivey that he is aware of the ward’s oppressive atmosphere, indicating situational awareness.
Dismisses Big Nurse’s concerns as just an 'old nurse and her fixed ways,' which might reflect underestimation of her power.

Complains bitterly about Nurse Ratched and situation but does not lash out at patients or staff.

Organizes Cheswick to support actions (carrying him to the basket, fetching Bromden), effectively coordinating others to achieve a goal.
Shows confidence and leadership by taking initiative and directing others.
Fails to recognize that Bromden does not hear or respond initially, which might cause slight confusion, but quickly adapts.

Wakes up Cheswick, Billy, Martini, and others to say goodbye before leaving, demonstrating care and consideration.
Wakes up multiple patients gently and strategically to wake the ward without causing alarm.
Announces his planned escape confidently but keeps the method secret, maintaining control and mystery.

Engages the other patients in a secret plan and encourages them to follow quietly, offering hope of an escape route.
Quietly asks the others to go back to bed to not ruin the plan, showing consideration for their wellbeing and the group's safety.
Confidently bets with Taber despite being told there's no way out and initiates a plan involving the dumbwaiter as a potential escape route.
Calms the others down, instructing them to keep quiet to avoid ruining the plan, demonstrating an understanding of the delicate situation and group control.
Organizes a group activity and encourages patients to stick together and stay alert.
Calls Martini and Scanlon 'dumb goons' to get their attention.
Organizes the other patients by calling out their names in order and reminding them of the rules and privileges, showing leadership and situational awareness.
Notices Martini and Scanlon going the wrong way and immediately tries to recall them, demonstrating attentiveness and quick reaction.

Insists on not going back, stating it's a one-way trip and demands others stand aside, showing confidence and leadership.

Waves Bromden onto the bus and encourages him to come along.

Responds patiently and supportively to Billy's nervous question about the destination.
Offers reassurance about food and warmth to the worried patients.
Waves Bromden onto the bus and confidently takes the initiative to start the bus moving despite uncertain circumstances.
Sings loudly and takes charge of the group's morale during an uncertain situation, showing leadership and confidence.

Leads the group on a fishing trip, ensuring everyone has necessary equipment and supplies.

Relaxes and listens to the ballgame with others, showing confident ease in the situation.

Remains calm and observant despite being bruised and restrained, taking in the new ward environment thoughtfully.
Does not immediately react impulsively to the oppressive atmosphere and patient distress, indicating composure and situational awareness.

Playfully orders aides to take a cigarette break in the EST room, lightening the mood.

Sits heavily and admits exhaustion, indicating physical limitations.

Recovers from sadness and reengages with others by moving and interacting.
